Graphical abstract The direct Z-schemes of the photocatalytic overall water splitting with the SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II heterostructures are constructed based on the density functional theory calculations and nonadiabatic molecular dynamics (NAMD) simulations. The maximum solar-to-hydrogen efficiency (ηʹ STH) reaches 19.18% and can be promoted to 28.71% under tensile biaxial strains. NAMD simulations indicate the transfer of the electron for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and hole for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) for SiSe/SnSe2 are apparently slower than those for the other two heterostructures, implicating the reduction and oxidation activities of this heterostructure are well-protected. Moreover, the shortest electron-hole recombination time is attributed to SiSe/SnSSe-I, indicating that it holds the best photocatalytic performance. Remarkably, the Gibbs free energies indicate that HER and OER with SiSe/SnSSe-I can spontaneously proceed, while OERs can but HERs cannot spontaneously proceed with the other two heterostructures. Therefore, the newfound heterostructures, especially SiSe/SnSSe-I, are promising candidates in photocatalytic overall water splitting. Keywords Solar-to-hydrogen Direct Z-scheme Hydrogen evolution reaction Photocatalytic Gibbs free energy Nonadiabatic molecular dynamics simulation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In facing the growing energy crises and environmental pollution, the photocatalytic water splitting with semiconductors and sunlight, which utilizes inexhaustible solar energy to convert into storable hydrogen energy [1,2], has been paid too much attention as a promising and sustainable technology and is expected to become a promising and superior alternative energy source to the nonrenewable fossil energy [3]. Two-dimensional (2D) semiconductor materials have received very broad attention in optoelectronic [4,5] and photocatalysis [6] because of their unequaled structural characteristics and electronic properties [7,8]. A photocatalyst for overall water splitting ought to simultaneously meet the requirements of the strong redox ability, efficient charge spatial separation, and wide light response range. However, it is difficult to have good compatibility between the high redox ability and broad light absorption range in the one-vacuum-level photocatalyst [9]. Moreover, the high electron-hole recombination rate substantially reduces the photocatalytic ability, leading to low photocatalytic efficiency [10]. Among various strategies, constructing van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures should be the promising one. However, the driving force of the conventional type-II heterostructures is weak and reduces the redox ability of charge carriers [11,12]. Fortunately, the direct Z-scheme heterostructures not only separate the photogenerated charge carriers but also retain the strong redox ability for driving photocatalytic reactions, although they also are staggered band alignments [13,14]. Accordingly, the photocatalytic efficiency is remarkably improved. For example, She et al. [15] experimentally reported that α-Fe2O3/g-C3N4 exhibits high efficiency toward overall water splitting without any co-catalytic donor. Chen et al. [16] showed that BP/BiVO4 can realize spontaneously solar-driven hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) to produce H2. In theory, researchers have tried to search for suitable 2D monolayers to construct high-performing heterostructures. For example, the solar-to-hydrogen (STH) efficiency (ηʹ STH) of the ZrSe2/GaAs3 heterostructure [17] constructed according to theoretical calculations can reach 42.71 %. The β-AsP/g-C3N4 was theoretically predicted to have an efficient HER with −0.02 eV Gibbs free energy [18]. The Co doping induces the distortion of MoS2, which can induce better photocatalytic performance for the Co-MoS2/g-C3N4 in comparison with the MoS2/g-C3N4 heterostructures [19]. However, heterostructures with direct Z-scheme can spontaneously proceed with HER and oxygen evolution reactions (OER) are rarely reported. Therefore, there is adequate space for screening heterostructures to spontaneously drive overall water splitting. Generally, the monolayers with suitable bandgaps and mobility are necessary for constructing a satisfactory vdW heterostructure with an efficient direct Z-scheme. Yang et al. [20] identified that the Pmma-SiS monolayer has a direct bandgap, high mobility, good optical absorption, and low thermal conductivity. This monolayer is more stable than α-SiS and β-SiS [21] and is considered a potential anode for lithium-ion batteries [22]. Zhou et al. [23] experimentally synthesized ultrathin SnSe2, while the SnSe2 monolayer with high carrier mobility and strong light absorption was considered a compelling candidate for photocatalysis [24,25]. However, the conduction band minimum (CBM) of the SnSe2 monolayer cannot match the conditions of photocatalytic HER [26]. Experimentally, some heterostructures, such as SnSe2/CdS [27] and ZnIn2S4/SnSe2, [28] have been prepared, which showed a superior activity for photocatalytic HER with visible light. In theory, the water splitting with BP/SnSe2 [29] heterostructure and sunlight was reported. Moreover, the direct Z-scheme with the MoX2(X = Se, Te) monolayers for HER while the SnSe2 monolayer for OER was designed for the MoX2(X = Se, Te)/SnSe2 heterostructures [30]. The Janus MoSSe monolayer had been synthesized by a controlled sulfurization process, which opens a door for manufacturing polarization materials [31]. Guo et al. [32] found that the 1 T-SnSSe monolayer has a high carrier mobility and absorption coefficient, indicating a potential photocatalytic application. Other theoretical calculations demonstrated that 1 T-SnSSe is more stable than the 2H allotrope one [33]. However, we fail to find the heterostructures composed of the SiSe, SnSe2, and SnSSe monolayers although these monolayers are suitable for constructing heterostructures for photocatalytic applications. In this study, we explore the stability, electronic properties, photogenerated carrier dynamics, and Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for the SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II heterostructures, based on the density functional theory (DFT) calculations and the non-adiabatic molecular dynamics (NAMD) simulations. The obtained band alignments and the built-in electric fields (E built-in) match the requirement of the photocatalytic direct Z-schemes with these heterostructures. Meanwhile, ηʹ STHs of the SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II can reach 19.18 %, 14.61 %, and 14.24 %, respectively. NAMD simulations indicate that the relaxations of the photoexcited carriers in SiSe/SnSe2 are slower than those in the other two heterostructures, implying that the photocatalytic activity of this heterostructure is well protected. The shortest electron-hole (e-h) recombination time of SiSe/SnSSe-I indicates that the most efficient photocatalytic Z-scheme is attributed to this heterostructure. The ΔG indicates that SiSe/SnSSe-I can spontaneously proceed both HER and OER, although the other considered ones can only trigger OER but cannot proceed HER spontaneously. Therefore, SiSe/SnSSe-I should be a competitive candidate material for overall water splitting. 2 Computational methods The first principles calculations are carried out using DFT in combination with the projector augmented wave (PAW) implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 6.3.0) [34,35]. The Heyd-Scuseria-Ernerh (HSE06) hybrid functional [36] is used in geometrical optimizations and static calculations. The plane-wave cutoff energy is 500 eV. The total energy and atomic forces on the atoms are 10-5 eV and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. According to the manual of VASP, a roughly uniform sampling of the Brillouin zone can be yielded when N 1, N 2, and N 3 are chosen such that: N 1: N 2: N 3 ≅ 1: a/b: a/c. Here, a, b and c are lattice parameters. For the present 2D structure, b = 7a/4 will result in a k-point mesh of 7 × 4 × 1. A z-direction vacuum space of 15 Å is utilized to avoid the influence of near slabs. The vdW interactions are necessary for optimizing the correct geometrical structure of heterostructure. We used the density functional dispersion correction (DFT-D4) [37] to evaluate the vdW interactions in the heterostructure because it has several advantages [38]. DFT-D4 offers improved accuracy in describing dispersion interactions compared to earlier versions, such as DFT-D2 [39] and DFT-D3 [40]. The higher-order dispersion terms that capture more accurately the long-range interactions are also included. This allows for a more comprehensive treatment of dispersion forces, especially in larger and more complex systems. DFT-D4 is designed to be transferable across a wide range of molecular systems, making it applicable to diverse areas of chemistry and materials science. This transferability is crucial for a method to be widely adopted and applicable to various types of molecular interactions. Moreover, the results by DFT-D4 are more consistent with experimental data for various systems, providing more reliable predictions of molecular structures, interaction energies, and other properties. While dispersion corrections add an extra layer of complexity to the calculations, DFT-D4 has been optimized for computational efficiency. This allows researchers to include accurate dispersion corrections without an excessive increase in computational cost. DFT-D4 can be used with a variety of density functionals, making it versatile and compatible with different flavors of DFT. The dipole correction [41] is introduced to include the effect of the asymmetry charge distribution. The CASTEP code [42] in the Materials Studio software is used to evaluate the phonon dispersions via the linear response [43] with a convergence tolerance of 10-7. Norm-conserving pseudopotential [44] with 1000 eV of cutoff energy is utilized. The energy, maximum force, and maximum displacement standards are 10-7 eV, 10-2 eV/Å, and 10-4 Å, respectively. The ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations with the ensemble (NVT) [45] are carried out to confirm the thermodynamic stability. The temperature is 300 K and the time is 5 ps with a time step of 1.0 fs. A 5-ps trajectory is generated by using AIMD with the microcanonical ensemble (NVE). The NAMD simulations are implemented in the Hefei-NAMD codes [46], by using a quantum–classical decoherence-induced surface-hopping (DISH) method in the Kohn-Sham framework [47,48]. The codes have been used to investigate nonadiabatic dynamics behaviors for many heterostructures. For example, the transfer and recombination times between electrons and holes are simulated by Hefei-NAMD codes for the C7N6/GaSnPS [49], CdS/C6N7 [50], the cascade dual Z-schemes for InAs3/HfSeTe/ZrSe2 [51] and the SbNR-CN/AsNR-CN nanoribbon heterostructure [52]. For each selected initial configuration, we select 1000 random initial configurations and 2000 surface-hopping trajectories. The calculational details of the carrier mobility, ηʹ STH, optical absorption, and ΔG can be found in Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Geometries, stabilities, and electronic properties of the SiSe, SnSe2 and SnSSe monolayers The optimized structures of the SiSe, SnSe2, and SnSSe monolayers with the Pmma, P 3 ¯ m1, and P3m1 groups are represented in Fig. S1, while the obtained lattice parameters are 3.900/6.873, 3.773/6.534, and 3.696/6.400 Å, respectively. The lattice parameters of SiSe correspond to the previously reported 3.912/6.683 Å [22], while those of SnSe2 and SnSSe are comparable to the 3.82 and 3.784 Å for the rhombus primitive cell [32,53], respectively. The phonon dispersions in Fig. S2 confirm the dynamic stabilities of the SiSe, SnSe2, and SnSSe monolayers because no imaginary frequencies have been found. The structures in Figs. S3(a-c) show a small potential energy fluctuation around the initial value, indicating the three monolayers are thermodynamically stable. Fig. S4 shows the band structures and the partial density of states (PDOS) for the three monolayers, indicating that the SiSe and SnSSe monolayers have direct bandgaps of 1.50 and 1.76 eV, which are comparable to 1.35 [54] and 1.61 [33] eV in the literature, respectively. The SnSe2 monolayer has an indirect bandgap of 1.51 eV close to the previous 1.48 eV [29]. Therefore, all three monolayers can well respond to sunlight. The work function ( Δ Φ F ) difference between the two monolayers in heterostructures is essential for the redistribution of charge and built-in electric field formation at the interface [55]. We calculated the Δ Φ F by using the electrostatic potential E v a c and Fermi level E F . The E v a c / E F for SiSe, SnSe2 and SnSSe monolayer are 3.19/-1.89, 2.47/-3.83, and (2.71/2.44)/-3.92 eV, respectively, as shown in Figure S5. The obtained Δ Φ F values are 5.08, 6.30 and 6.63/6.36 eV, respectively. The smaller Δ Φ F of the SiSe monolayer means that the electrons will migrate from the SiSe monolayer to the SnSe2 or SnSSe monolayers until the same Fermi level is reached in the interface when the heterostructures are formed [9]. The absolute band edge E C B M / V B M A b s for evaluating overpotentials is calculated by: [56] (1) E C B M / V B M A b s = E C B M / V B M H S E 06 - E v a c where E C B M / V B M H S E 06 stands for the HSE06 energies of CBM and VBM. E v a c can be abstracted from Figs. S5(a-c). The E C B M / V B M A b s of the SiSe monolayer is −3.81/-5.30 eV. Similarly, the E C B M / V B M A b s s of the SnSe2 and SnSSe monolayer are −5.00/-6.62 and −5.09/-6.57 eV, respectively. The E C B M A b s of SiSe is higher than the reduction potential of H+/H2, but the oxidation potential for H2O/O2 is lower than the E V B M A b s . For SnSe2 and SnSSe, although the E V B M A b s is lower than the oxidation potential of H2O/O2, the E C B M A b s is lower than the reduction potential of H+/H2. Each of the monolayers cannot fully meet the requirements for photocatalytic overall water splitting. The carrier mobility μ is also a very crucial factor in assessing the photoelectronic performance of semiconductor materials. Figs. S6-S8 and Table S1 collect the calculated μs for the SiSe, SnSe2, and SnSSe monolayers, which demonstrates an obvious anisotropy characteristic because those along the x and y directions are substantially different. Some mobilities, for example, those for the electron of the SiSe, the y direction of the electron and hole of the SnSSe, and the electron of SnSe2 monolayers are much superior to the ones of other novel 2D materials, such as WS2 (542 cm2V-1s−1) [57], MoS2 (<400 cm2V-1s−1) [58]. Hence, the evident spatial charge separation of the photogenerated electron-hole pairs, and the rapid transfer of the photogenerated electron within the monolayers are expected, resulting in a positive impact on the photoelectronic efficiency. 3.2 Z-schemes for the SiSe/SnSe2 and SiSe/SnSSe heterostructure The lattice mismatch ratio between the SiSe and SnSe2 monolayers is 4.9 %. The Janus SnSSe monolayer can result in two different stacking patterns (represented by SiSe/SnSSe-I and SiSe/SnSSe-II) with the S or Se atoms confronting the SiSe monolayer. However, as shown in Fig. 1 , the lattice mismatch ratios are the same value of 6.8 %. The calculated interlayer distances (d ij) are 3.60, 3.58, and 3.65 Å, which fall within the range of the vdW interaction [59]. The formation energies E f s of the SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II heterostructures are calculated to assess the relative energy stability by: [60]. (2) E f = E Hetero - E SiSe - E SnSe 2 / SnSSe A where E H e t e r o is the energy of the heterostructure. E S i S e and E S n S e 2 / S n S S e represent the energies of the isolated SiSe and SnSe2/SnSSe monolayers, respectively. A is the area of the conventional supercell of the heterostructure. The more negative E f indicates the higher stability of relevant heterostructure. The E f s of the considered configurations are −13.33, −7.22, and −8.05 meV/Å2, which are comparable with those of some previous heterostructures [49,61] in the literature. The average bond energies between the atoms in the two monolayers are 31.63, 16.77, and 18.64 meV for SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II, respectively, which correspond to the vdW energy of 4.146–41.457 meV [59]. As shown in Figs. S3(d-f), the energies by the AIMD simulations at 300 K in 5 ps demonstrate that the geometrical structures are well preserved and all atoms vibrate around their equilibrium positions after 3 ps, indicating the constructed heterostructures are thermodynamically stable. Fig. 2 demonstrates that the band alignments of the three heterostructures all belong to a stagger arrangement, which matches the prerequisite for the direct Z-scheme. Moreover, the VBMs of the three heterostructures are all contributed by those of the SiSe monolayer (represented by VBM@SiSe), while CBMs are attributed to the ones of the SnSe2 or SnSSe (represented by CBM@SnSe2 or CBM@SnSSe). The PDOS shows that the Se atom mainly contributes the VBM@SiSe. Se and Sn contribute the CBM@SnSe2 of the SiSe/SnSe2, while Sn and S contribute the CBM@SnSSe of the SiSe/SnSSe-I and SiSe/SnSSe-II. To determine the direction of E built-in, we calculate the plane-averaged charge density difference Δ ρ by [62]: (3) Δ ρ = ρ H e t - ρ S i S e - ρ S n S e 2 / S n S S e where ρ H e t are the chargedensity for the SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II heterostructures, while ρ S i S e and ρ S n S e 2 / S n S S e represent those of the free-standing SiSe, SnSe2, and SnSSe monolayers, respectively. As shown in Fig. S10, an obvious redistribution of the charge density is observed at the interface of the three heterostructures. The charge depletion (on the SiSe monolayer) and accumulation zone (on the SnSe2/SnSSe monolayer) indicate the effective charge separation. Moreover, Bader charge analysis [63] quantitatively gives the electron transfer from the SiSe to the SnSe2 or SnSSe monolayers are 0.0005, 0.014, and 0.0006 e for SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II, respectively. The different charge transfers in SiSe/SnSSe-I and SiSe/SnSSe-II indicate the stacking patterns can substantially impact the charge transfer. The direction of the electron transfer can also be understood from the work function differences of the SiSe (5.08 eV), SnSe2 (6.30 eV), and SnSSe (6.63/6.35 eV) monolayers. The charge transfer could induce E built-ins from SiSe to SnSe2 or SnSSe monolayers when heterostructures are formed, as shown in Fig. 3 . These E built-ins can generate a driving force to accelerate the recombination of the photogenerated hole at VBM@SiSe and the photogenerated electron at CBM@SnSe2 or CBM@SnSSe. Meanwhile, the E built-in also suppresses the photogenerated electron to transfer from CBM@SiSe to CBM@SnSe2 or CBM@SnSSe and the hole to transfer from VBM@SnSe2 or VBM@SnSSe to VBM@SiSe of the heterostructures. Therefore, both the obtained band alignments and the E built-in support to construct Z-schemes for the three heterostructures. Based on the band edges of each monolayer projected from the band alignment of the heterostructures, we designed the Z-schemes for SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II according to E built-in and charge populations of the band edges, as shown in Fig. 3. According to the band edges in Table S2, all the constructed schemes satisfy the photocatalytic overall water splitting conditions. The optical absorption is evaluated to understand the response-ability of the monolayers separated from the heterostructures to light. In the visible light region, the SnSe2 and SnSSe monolayers possess larger absorptions in comparison with that of the SiSe monolayer, as shown in Fig. S9. The optical absorption of the SnSe2 monolayer increases rapidly in the near-ultraviolet regions. Therefore, all three monolayers can efficiently harvest solar energy to generate photoelectrons. 3.3 STH efficiency and strain engineering The STH efficiency ηʹ STH is calculated by using the overpotentials of HER/OER and bandgaps [64]. Based on the band edges in Table S2 and the electrostatic potential difference ΔΦ in Fig. S5, the ηʹ STHs are obtained and presented in Fig. 4 . The ηʹ STH free of strain (0 % in the figure) are 19.18 %, 14.61 %, and 14.24 % for the SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II heterostructures, respectively. These ηʹ STHs are larger than 10.5 % of the MoSe2/SnSe2 heterostructure [65] that has been fabricated in experiments. Moreover, the present ηʹ STHs are higher in comparison with 9.45 % for the RuI2/Sb2S3 [66], 10.60 % for the CrS3/GeSe [67], and 9.67 % for the InTe/Bismuthene [68] heterostructures. Therefore, the three considered heterostructures show promise in developing highly efficient photocatalysts for the overall water splitting to produce hydrogen. The strain energy E s is utilized to understand the stability of the systems under strains. Here, E s = (E strained - E unstrained)/n with E strained and E unstrained representing the energies of the strained or unstrained heterostructures. At the same time, the number of atoms in the cell is represented by n [69]. The strain energy curve ought to exhibit a parabolic trend when strains remain within the elastic limits, indicating that the heterostructure is stable in energy. Fig. 4(a-c) demonstrates the stability of the SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II can be maintained under the strains of a maximum of 11 %, 11%, and 7%. As a result, the ηʹ STH values can be boosted to 28.71 %, 27.78 %, and 18.37 % under tensile biaxial strains, respectively. As shown in Tables S3-S5, the compressive biaxial strains induce the increased bandgap and ΔΦ, as a result, an apparent decrease of ηʹ STH has been observed for SiSe/SnSSe-I. For the SiSe/SiSe2 and SiSe/SnSSe-II, the directions of the E built-in become inverse under the compressive biaxial strains and lead to a photocatalytic type-II scheme for the two heterostructures. To make matters worse, the overpotentials no longer meet the overall photocatalytic water-splitting conditions. Moreover, the band alignment of the SiSe/SnSSe-II heterostructure turns out to be type III when the tensile strain exceeds 8 %. So, these strains should be avoided to maintain high ηʹ STHs in the photocatalytic HER and OER. 3.4 Nonadiabatic transfer and recombination of the photogenerated carriers The nonadiabatic transferring and recombination of the photogenerated carriers in the present heterostructures with direct Z-scheme involve three processes: ① the electron transfer from CBM@SiSe to CBM@SnSe2/SnSSe, ② the hole transfer from VBM@SnSe2/SnSSe to VBM@SiSe, ③ the interlayer e-h recombination between the electrons from CBM@SnSe2/SnSSe and the holes from VBM@SiSe, as shown in Fig. 3. The above processes can be simulated by NAMD, which is highly reliant on the non-adiabatic coupling (NAC) factor defined as: (4) d ij = 〈 φ i ∂ ∂ t φ j 〉 = 〈 φ i ∇ R H ^ φ j 〉 ε j - ε i R ̇ where d ij is the NAC between states i and j, H ^ is the Kohn-Sham Hamiltonian, φ i / j and ε i / j are the wave functions and corresponding eigenvalues for i and j states, respectively, while R ̇ is the nuclei velocity [70,71]. Generally, the smaller energy gap ( ε j - ε i ), the larger electron–phonon (e-p) coupling 〈 φ i ∇ R H ^ φ j 〉 , and the faster nuclei velocity R ̇ mean a larger NAC [72]. The 〈 φ i ∇ R H ^ φ j 〉 term is corresponding to the first-order e-p matrix element [73]. The corresponding phonon mode can be visualized by the Fourier transforms (FT) of the normalized autocorrelation function (ACF) of the energy difference fluctuation between the donor and acceptor states to reveal the effect of e-p interaction on the carrier transfer and recombination [74]. Fig. 5 (a-c) shows that the energy gap between CBM@SiSe and its adjacent conduction band levels of SnSe2 is evidently larger than those of the other two heterostructures, while the energy gap between CBM@SiSe and its adjacent conduction band levels of SnSSe-I or SnSSe-II is nearly the same. As illustrated in Fig. 5(d-f), the main phonon modes for the three considered heterostructures are attributed to the frequency below 300 cm−1 that mostly comes from the strong interlayer interaction. In the electron transfer process, the peaks for SiSe/SnSSe-II are more and higher than those for SiSe/SnSe2 and SiSe/SnSSe-I. The phonon mode with the highest frequency of 200.13 cm−1 is assigned to the out-of-plane vibrations. However, there is only one dominant peak of 66.71 cm−1 for SiSe/SnSSe-I, which is attributed to the out-plane Si-Se, Sn-S(Se) bonds and in-plane Si-Si bonds. Usually, the high-frequency modes produce the larger R ̇ , which enhances NAC [75]. So, the smaller the energy gap, the larger 〈 φ i ∇ R H ^ φ j 〉 and R ̇ lead to a larger NAC of electron transfer in SiSe/SnSSe-II, as shown in Fig. 5. Moreover, the out-of-plane modes enlarge the interlayer wave function overlap and increase the e-p coupling, leading to larger NAC [76]. Similarly, the energy gap between VBM@SnSe2 and the adjacent valence band level of SiSe is larger than those of the other two heterostructures. The 〈 φ i ∇ R H ^ φ j 〉 is largest for the hole transfer in SiSe/SnSe2 due to the most peaks, but the peak at 200.13 cm−1 is assigned to the in-plane mode (see Fig. S11). Therefore, the NAC of the hole transfer process in SiSe/SnSe2 is still the smallest. Besides, there is no significant gap difference between VBM@SnSSe-I or VBM@SnSSe-II and the adjacent valence band level of SiSe. The phonon mode and R ̇ in SiSe/SnSSe-I for hole transfer are comparable to those of in SiSe/SnSSe-II, leading to NACs are 0.14 and 0.11 eV in the hole transfer process in SiSe/SnSSe-I and SiSe/SnSSe-II, respectively. Therefore, the NAC of the hole transfer in SiSe/SnSSe-I is the largest one. For the e-h recombination process, the energy gap between the VBM@SiSe and CBM@ SnSSe-I is the smallest, while those of VBM@SiSe and CBM@SnSe2 or CBM@SnSSe-II are almost the same. Also, the dominant peak at 66.71 cm−1 for the e-h recombination in SiSe/SnSSe-I is attributed to the out-plane mode (see Fig. S12). Although there is a dominant and a weak peaks in SiSe/SnSSe-II, the energy gap plays an important role in NAC. Hence, the NACs of SiSe/SnSSe-I and SiSe/SnSSe-II are 0.0030 and 0.0024 eV, respectively. Even though the e-h recombination in SiSe/SnSe2 couples with more phonon mode and higher peaks, the NAC is still the smallest with 0.0019 eV. As a result, the largest NAC for the electron transfer process is in SiSe/SnSSe-II, and those of hole transfer and e-h recombination are both in SiSe/SnSSe-I. The lifetime τ of the photogenerated carriers transfer is obtained by fitting the DISH population evolution curves relative to time into the exponential function f(t) = exp (−t/τ) [77], while the times of the e-h recombination processes are determined with the intersection points of the f(t) curves for the electron population on CBM@SnSe2/CBM@SnSSe and VBM@SiSe. As shown in Fig. 6 , The lifetimes of the interlayer transfer process for electron/hole are 33.89/15.04, 1.23/0.27, and 0.25/0.21 ps for SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I and SiSe/SnSSe-II, respectively. Apparently, the transfers of the electrons on CBM@SiSe for HER and holes on VBM@SnSe2 for OER in SiSe/SnSe2 are slower than those for other ones, implicating the photocatalytic activity of this heterostructure is better protected [78]. Moreover, the shortest e-h recombination time of 32.29 ps for SiSe/SnSSe-I means it is superior to the other two heterostructures in the photocatalytic performance with the direct Z-scheme. However, the e-h recombination time for the SiSe/SnSe2 is long compared to the other two heterostructures, which is not helpful for photocatalytic performance with Z-scheme. 3.5 Thermodynamic feasibility The Gibbs free energies ΔGs of OER and HER are computed to understand the thermodynamic feasibilities of the Z-schemes with SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II. For these heterostructures, the Z-schemes mean that the HERs occur at CBM@SiSe while the OERs reside on VBM@SnSe2 or VBM@SnSSe. The potential energies of the photogenerated electrons for HER (eU e) and holes for OER (eU h) are defined as the difference between the potential energy proceeding HER and E C B M A b s / E V B M A b s [79]. Therefore, if the absolute values of eU e and eU h are larger than the corresponding ΔGs, respectively, both the HER and OER can spontaneously proceed. Here, we use Δ G H ∗ and Δ G m a x to represent the maximum ΔGs for HER and OER, respectively. The optimal adsorption sites and structures are shown in Fig. 7 . The nonequivalent absorption sites and the absorption energies for the intermediates in HER and OER are listed in Tables S6-S11. For SiSe/SnSe2 and SiSe/SnSSe-I, the H atom is more inclined to be adsorbed on the Se atoms and the Δ G H ∗ are 1.20 and 1.09 eV (see Fig. 7), respectively, while the H atom prefers to be bonded to the Si atom for SiSe/SnSSe-II and Δ G H ∗ is 1.23 eV. The eU e for SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II are 1.01, 1.18, and 1.19 eV at PH = 0, respectively. Therefore, only the HER with SiSe/SnSSe-I can spontaneously proceed. The maximum external energies of 0.22 and 0.10 eV are needed to run HER with SiSe/SnSe2 and SiSe/SnSSe-II, respectively. In ideal HER activity, the Gibbs free energy ΔG H* should be close to zero. However, only some catalysts can proceed HER with the ideal condition. Therefore, additional treatments are used to promote the performance of the HER with a larger ΔG H*. Generally, a small absolute value of ΔG H* implies high thermodynamical feasibility. The present HERs have absolute values of ΔG H* larger than 1.0 eV. However, they are still thermodynamically feasible because some previous HERs with ΔG H* larger than the present ones are realized experimentally with the help of additional treatments. For example, Chen et al. [80] developed a nitrogen-anion decorated Ni3S2 directly grown on nickel foam substrate (N-Ni3S2/NF), which successfully enhances Ni3S2/NF to drive HER with ΔG H* of 2.5 eV. According to the experimental investigations of Kuznetsov et al. [81] the Mo2CO2 and Mo2CO2: Co can drive the HER with the Δ G H ∗ s smaller than 1.5 eV. Fortunately, the present Δ G H ∗ s with the HERs on the SiSe/SnSe2 and SiSe/SnSSe-II heterostructures fall into this range, suggesting that these HERs are also feasible in thermodynamics if some additional treatments are used in a similar way in the literature. Moreover, the OER on VBM@SnSe2 and VBM@SnSSe can proceed with two possible routes of single- or dual-site process involving the OOH* or O*OH* [82]. Fig. 7 and Tables S12-14 demonstrate that the rate-limiting steps for the single-site process occur at the reactions with the product of OOH*. Differently, for the dual-site process, the first steps with OH* are the rate-limiting steps, indicating that the dual-site reaction is more energetically favorable in comparison with the single-site reaction for the three heterostructures. Besides, the Δ G m a x s for the OERs with dual-site are 1.83, 1.97, and 1.74 eV for SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II, respectively. Therefore, the eU hs of 2.29, 2.44, and 2.75 eV are larger than the Δ G m a x s, indicating these OERs can spontaneously proceed with a dual-site process for the considered heterostructures. 4 Conclusions To summarize, the efficiently photocatalytic direct Z-schemes for overall water splitting are constructed for the SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II heterostructures according to electronic properties by the first-principles calculations, and the transferring and recombination mechanism of the photogenerated carriers are elucidated based on the NAMD simulations. The ηʹ STH values evaluated by using the overpotentials and bandgaps can reach 19.18 %, 14.61 %, and 14.24 % for the three heterostructures. The tensile strains can promote despite the compressive ones can decrease the ηʹ STHs. Remarkably, the maximum ηʹ STH of 28.71 % can be achieved for SiSe/SnSe2 by 11 % tensile biaxial strain. Thus, it is advisable to avoid any compressive strain to maintain the high photocatalytic performance. The transfer of the electron and hole for the SiSe/SnSe2 heterostructure is apparently slower than those for the other two ones, implicating that the photocatalytic activity of this heterostructure is better protected. SiSe/SnSSe-I possesses the smallest e-h recombination time, making it the superior one among the considered heterostructures in performance with the Z-scheme. The calculated ΔGs reveal that the photogenerated holes and electrons enable to spontaneously proceed both HER and OER with SiSe/SnSSe-I, although only OER can proceed spontaneously with SiSe/SnSe2 and SiSe/SnSSe-II. However, all the considered photocatalytic Z-schemes for overall water splitting are feasible if suitable additional treatments are provided. Therefore, the newfound heterostructures are promising candidates for the photocatalyst to generate hydrogen with overall water splitting. Undoubtedly, the SiSe/SnSSe-I heterostructure is the most promising one among the considered heterostructures. coredata.dc:description: The direct Z-schemes of the photocatalytic overall water splitting with the SiSe/SnSe2, SiSe/SnSSe-I, and SiSe/SnSSe-II heterostructures are constructed based on the density functional theory calculations and nonadiabatic molecular dynamics (NAMD) simulations. The maximum solar-to-hydrogen efficiency (ηʹ STH) reaches 19.18% and can be promoted to 28.71% under tensile biaxial strains. NAMD simulations indicate the transfer of the electron for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and hole for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) for SiSe/SnSe2 are apparently slower than those for the other two heterostructures, implicating the reduction and oxidation activities of this heterostructure are well-protected. Moreover, the shortest electron-hole recombination time is attributed to SiSe/SnSSe-I, indicating that it holds the best photocatalytic performance. Remarkably, the Gibbs free energies indicate that HER and OER with SiSe/SnSSe-I can spontaneously proceed, while OERs can but HERs cannot spontaneously proceed with the other two heterostructures. Therefore, the newfound heterostructures, especially SiSe/SnSSe-I, are promising candidates in photocatalytic overall water splitting.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogen generation from direct Z-scheme for photocatalytic overall water splitting with the SiSe/SnSe2 and SiSe/SnSSe heterostructures
